labelLink.label: Statement of Net Position [Abstract]
Information about the Statement of Net Position.
Statement of Net Position Type of Activities [Abstract]
Information about the Statement of Net Position.
Statement of Net Position [Table]
Used to represent data reported in the Statement of Net Position.
Type of Activities [Axis]
Used as an identifier for Governmental activities or Business type activities. If Primary Governmental activities needs to be represented, do not use an axis.
Type of Activities [Domain]
Information about type of activities. Use for Governmental or Business activities. If Primary Government activities need to be represented, do not use an axis.
Governmental Activities [Member]

Governmental activities which are generally are financed through taxes, intergovernmental revenues, and other non-exchange revenues. These activities are usually reported in governmental funds and internal service funds.
Business Type Activities [Member]

Represents business-type activities, which is one of two classes of activities reported in government-wide financial statements. Business-type activities are financed in whole or in part by fees charged to external parties for goods or services. These activities usually are reported in enterprise funds.
Statement of Net Position [Line Items]
Used to collect information found on a Statement of Net Position, Primary Government.
Assets [Abstract]
Information about assets.
Current Assets [Abstract]
Information about Current Assets.
Cash and Cash Equivalents

Currency, coins, checks, money orders, and bankers' drafts on hand or on deposit with an official or agent designated as custodian of cash or demand deposits with financial institutions. Cash equivalents are short-term highly liquid investments including Treasury bills, commercial paper, and money market funds. Use PeriodEnd or PeriodStart labels to represent end of period or start of period balance.
Restricted Cash

Amount of cash restricted as to withdrawal or usage. Cash includes, but is not limited to, currency on hand, demand deposits with banks or financial institutions, and other accounts with general characteristics of demand deposits.
Cash and Cash Equivalents with Fiscal and Escrow and Other agents

Cash and cash equivalents with fiscal and escrow and other agents. Cash includes not only currency on hand, but also demand deposits with banks or other financial institutions. Cash also includes deposits in other kinds of accounts or cash management pools that have the general characteristics of demand deposit accounts in that the governmental enterprise may deposit additional cash at any time and also effectively may withdraw cash at any time without prior notice or penalty.
Cash and Cash Equivalents with Treasurer

Cash and cash equivalents with treasurer. Cash includes not only currency on hand, but also demand deposits with banks or other financial institutions. Cash also includes deposits in other kinds of accounts or cash management pools that have the general characteristics of demand deposit accounts in that the governmental enterprise may deposit additional cash at any time and also effectively may withdraw cash at any time without prior notice or penalty.
Cash and Cash Equivalents with Trustee

Cash and cash equivalents with trustee. Cash includes not only currency on hand, but also demand deposits with banks or other financial institutions. Cash also includes deposits in other kinds of accounts or cash management pools that have the general characteristics of demand deposit accounts in that the governmental enterprise may deposit additional cash at any time and also effectively may withdraw cash at any time without prior notice or penalty.
Cash and Cash Equivalents, Others

Represents other cash and cash equivalents that the reporting entity does not separately disclose in the same statement or note. Cash includes not only currency on hand, but also demand deposits with banks or other financial institutions. Cash also includes deposits in other kinds of accounts or cash management pools that have the general characteristics of demand deposit accounts in that the governmental enterprise may deposit additional cash at any time and also effectively may withdraw cash at any time without prior notice or penalty.
Cash and Cash Equivalents and Investments

Cash and cash equivalents and investments includes not only currency on hand, but also demand deposits with banks or other financial institutions. Cash also includes deposits in other kinds of accounts or cash management pools that have the general characteristics of demand deposit accounts in that the governmental enterprise may deposit additional cash at any time and also effectively may withdraw cash at any time without prior notice or penalty. Investments amounts pertaining to a security or other asset that (a) a government holds primarily for the purpose of income or profit and (b) has a present service capacity based solely on its ability to generate cash or to be sold to generate cash.
Cash and Investments

Cash and investments. Cash includes not only currency on hand, but also demand deposits with banks or other financial institutions. Cash also includes deposits in other kinds of accounts or cash management pools that have the general characteristics of demand deposit accounts in that the governmental enterprise may deposit additional cash at any time and also effectively may withdraw cash at any time without prior notice or penalty. Investments amounts pertaining to a security or other asset that (a) a government holds primarily for the purpose of income or profit and (b) has a present service capacity based solely on its ability to generate cash or to be sold to generate cash.
Investments, Current
Securities that are expected to be held for less than one year and that generate revenue in the form of interest or dividents.
Pooled Cash and Investments

Pooled cash and investments. Cash includes not only currency on hand, but also demand deposits with banks or other financial institutions. Cash also includes deposits in other kinds of accounts or cash management pools that have the general characteristics of demand deposit accounts in that the governmental enterprise may deposit additional cash at any time and also effectively may withdraw cash at any time without prior notice or penalty.
Investments with State Treasury

Investments with state treasury, which is the amounts pertaining to a security or other asset that (a) a government holds primarily for the purpose of income or profit and (b) has a present service capacity based solely on its ability to generate cash or to be sold to generate cash.
Investments with Fiscal Agents

Investments with fiscal agents, which is the amounts pertaining to a security or other asset that (a) a government holds primarily for the purpose of income or profit and (b) has a present service capacity based solely on its ability to generate cash or to be sold to generate cash.
Pooled Investments

Pooled investments. Investments amounts pertaining to a security or other asset that (a) a government holds primarily for the purpose of income or profit and (b) has a present service capacity based solely on its ability to generate cash or to be sold to generate cash.
Other Current Investments

Other current investments which the reporting entity does not separately disclose in the same statement or note. Investments amounts pertaining to a security or other asset that (a) a government holds primarily for the purpose of income or profit and (b) has a present service capacity based solely on its ability to generate cash or to be sold to generate cash.
Income Tax Receivable
Income tax receivable which are taxes derived from state income tax.
Property Taxes Receivable
Property taxes receivable. Property taxes are ad-valorem taxes levied on an assessed valuation of real property.
Special Assessment Taxes Receivable
Special assessment taxes receivable, derived from state, municipal or school districts.
Sales Tax Receivable
Sales tax receivable. Sales tax is a tax imposed upon the sale or consumption of goods.
Payments in Lieu of Taxes Receivable
Revenue in lieu of taxes receivable.
Other Taxes Receivable
Other taxes receivable which the reporting entity does not separately disclose in the same statement or note.
Grants Receivable
Grants receivable.
Leases Receivable
Leases receivable.
Accounts Receivable
Accounts receivable.
Inter Governmental Receivable

Inter-governmental receivable is appropriate where one governmental unit transfers resources to another, such as when states transfer shared revenues to local governments or act as an Intermediary in federally financed programs.
Internal Balances Receivable
Internal balances receivable, which are net residual amounts due between governmental and business-type activities in the government-wide statement of net position.
Deposits Receivable
Deposits receivable.
Notes Receivable
Notes receivable.
Loans Receivable
Loans receivable.
Penalties Receivable
Penalties receivable.
Claims and Judgments Receivable
Claims and judgments receivable.
Investment Income Receivable
Investment income receivable, which is the compensation for the use of financial resources over a period of time.
Receivables from Contracts
Receivables from contracts.
Receivables (Net of Allowance Where Applicable)
Amounts owed by private persons, firms, governmental units, or others, except for interfund receivables and are net of allowances for uncollectible accounts where applicable.
Interest Receivable
Carrying amount as of the balance sheet date of interest earned but not received. Also called accrued interest or accrued interest receivable.
Tuition and Fees Receivable
Tuition and other associated fees, for example, registration.
Other Receivables

Other receivables which the reporting entity does not separately disclose in the same statement or note. It is the total due to the entity within one year of the balance sheet date (or one operating cycle, if longer) from outside sources, including trade accounts receivable, notes and loans receivable, as well as any other types of receivables, net of allowances established for the purpose of reducing such receivables to an amount that approximates their net realizable value.
Due from Primary Government Entities
Due from primary government entities.
Due from Component Unit
Due from component unit.
Due from Other Government Entities
Due from other government entities that the reporting entity does not separately disclose in the same statement or note.
Due from Fiduciary Funds
Due from fiduciary funds.
Due from Entities Funds
Due from entities funds.
Due from Other Funds
Due from other funds amounts that the reporting entity does not separately disclose in the same statement or note.
Due from Others
Due from others.
Receivables
Amounts owed by private individuals or organizations for goods and services furnished by a government.
Tuition and Fees Allowances
The portion of tuition and fees receivable estimated not to be collectible.
Allowance for Property Taxes
The portion of property taxes receivable estimated not to be collectible.
Allowance for Uncollectible Interest
The portion of interest receivable estimated not to be collectible.
Allowance for Uncollectible Receivables
The portion of receivables estimated not to be collectible.
Accumulated Depreciation and Amortization
The total amount of depreciation expense that has been recorded from the time the asset was put into service until the date of the balance sheet.
Accumulated Depreciation
The accumulation of systematic and rational allocations of the estimated cost of using assets, on a historical basis, over the useful life of the assets.
Inventories, Current
Inventories, classified as current, which are materials and supplies on hand for future consumption or goods held for resale rather than for use in operations.
Prepaid Expenses
Prepaid expenses which is an asset resulting from the payment for goods or services to be received in the future.
Prepaid Deposits
Prepaid deposits which is an asset resulting from the payment for goods or services to be received in the future.
Prepaid OPEB
Prepaid other post-employment benefits plan, which is an asset resulting from the payment for services to be received in the future.
Other Prepaid Assets

Other prepaid assets which the reporting entity does not separately disclose in the same statement or note. It is an asset resulting from the payment for goods or services to be received in the future.
Securities Lending Collateral, Assets
Securities lending collateral, assets.
Regulatory Assets, Current
Regulatory assets, classified as current.
Derivative Instruments Assets, Current
Derivative instruments assets, classified as current.
Other Current Assets
Other current assets which the reporting entity does not separately disclose in the same statement.
Current Assets
Current Assets.
Restricted Assets
Restricted assets should be reported when restrictions on asset use change the nature or normal understanding of the availability of the asset.
Noncurrent Assets [Abstract]
Information about noncurrent assets.
Capital Assets Non Depreciable and NonAmortizable
Capital assets that are non depreciable or non amortizable.
Capital Assets, Depreciable (Net of Accumulated Depreciation and Amortization)
Capital assets, classified as depreciable.
Investments in Subsidiaries

Investments in subsidiaries, which is the amounts pertaining to a security or other asset that (a) a government holds primarily for the purpose of income or profit and (b) has a present service capacity based solely on its ability to generate cash or to be sold to generate cash.
Investments in Joint Ventures

Investments in joint ventures, which is the amounts pertaining to a security or other asset that (a) a government holds primarily for the purpose of income or profit and (b) has a present service capacity based solely on its ability to generate cash or to be sold to generate cash.
Investments in Associates

Investments in associates, which is the amounts pertaining to a security or other asset that (a) a government holds primarily for the purpose of income or profit and (b) has a present service capacity based solely on its ability to generate cash or to be sold to generate cash.
Other Noncurrent Investments

Other noncurrent investments which the reporting entity does not separately disclose in the same statement or note. Investments amounts pertaining to a security or other asset that (a) a government holds primarily for the purpose of income or profit and (b) has a present service capacity based solely on its ability to generate cash or to be sold to generate cash.
Inventories, Noncurrent
Inventories, classified as noncurrent, which are materials and supplies on hand for future consumption or goods held for resale rather than for use in operations.
Regulatory Assets, Noncurrent
Regulatory assets, classified as noncurrent.
Derivative Instruments Assets, Noncurrent
Derivative instruments assets, classified as noncurrent.
Capital Assets

The amount after accumulated depreciation and amortization of physical assets such as land, improvements to land, easements, buildings, building improvements, vehicles, machinery, equipment, works of art and historical treasures, infrastructure, construction in progress, and all other tangible or intangible assets that have been, or will be, used in operations and that have initial useful lives extending beyond a single reporting period. Infrastructure assets are long-lived capital assets that normally are stationary in nature and can be preserved for a significantly greater number of years than most capital assets.
Net Pension Asset
Net pension asset.
Net OPEB Asset

An employer's net OPEB obligation is defined as the cumulative difference between annual OPEB cost and the employer's contributions to a plan, including the OPEB liability or asset at transition, if any. Use this concept when there is an OPEB asset.
Other Noncurrent Assets
Other noncurrent assets which the reporting entity does not separately disclose in the same statement or note.
Noncurrent Assets
noncurrent assets.
Assets Held for Resale
Held for resale assets are long -lived assets that have been previously bought, for which there is a concrete plan to dispose of the asset by sale.
Intangible Assets

An intangible asset is classified as a capital assets. It is an asset that lacks physical substance, is nonfinancial in nature, and has an initial useful life extending beyond a single reporting period.
Computer Software

Computer software is a common type of intangible asset that is often internally generated. Computer software should be considered internally generated if it is developed in-house by the government’s personnel or by a third-party contractor on behalf of the government. Commercially available software that is purchased or licensed by the government and modified using more than minimal incremental effort before being put into operation also should be considered internally generated.
Easements
An easement is a nonpossessory right to use and/or enter onto the real property of another without possessing it.
Patents

A patent is a form of intellectual property that gives its owner the legal right to exclude others from making, using, selling and importing an invention for a limited period of years, in exchange for publishing an enabling public disclosure of the invention.
Timber Rights
Timber rights are an interest in a property's timber that allows one to buy or sell the interest in the timber separately from the land.
Trademarks

A trademark is a type of intellectual property consisting of a recognizable sign, design, or expression which identifies products or services of a particular source from those of others, although trademarks used to identify services are usually called service marks.
Water Rights
Water rights are the right to legally appropriate water and put it to beneficial use now and in the future.
Assets
Resources with present service capacity that the government presently controls.
Deferred Outflows of Resources [Abstract]
Information about deferred outflows of resources.
Deferred Outflows of Resources, Debt Items
Consumption of debt related net assets that applies to a future period(s) and so will not be recognized as an outflow of resources (expense/expenditure) until then.
Deferred Outflows of Resources, OPEB Items
Consumption of OPEB related net assets that applies to a future period(s) and so will not be recognized as an outflow of resources (expense/expenditure) until then.
Deferred Outflows of Resources, OPEB Items, Changes in Assumptions

Consumption of OPEB related net assets deferred due to changes in assumptions about future economic and demographic factors such as inflation, health care costs trend rates, salary changes, ad hoc post‐employment benefit changes, and mortality rates. Applies to a future period(s) and so will not be recognized as an outflow of resources (expense/expenditure) until then.
Deferred Outflows of Resources, OPEB Items, Contributions Made After Measurement Date

Consumption of OPEB related net assets due to contributions to the OPEB plan made subsequent to the measurement date and prior to the reporting date. Applies to a future period(s) and so will not be recognized as an outflow of resources (expense/expenditure) until then.
Deferred Outflows of Resources, OPEB Items, Difference between Expected and Actual Experience

Consumption of OPEB related net assets deferreed due to differences between expected and actuarial experience with regard to economic or demographic factors. Applies to a future period(s) and so will not be recognized as an outflow of resources (expense/expenditure) until then.
Deferred Outflows of Resources, OPEB Items, Net Difference Projected and Actual Earnings on Pension Plan Investments

Consumption of OPEB related net assets arising from difference between projected and actual OPEB plan investment earnings. Applies to a future period(s) and so will not be recognized as an outflow of resources (expense/expenditure) until then.
Deferred Outflows of Resources, OPEB, Changes in Proportion and Differences Between Employer Contributions and Share of Contributions

Consumption of net assets applicable to changes in the employer’s proportion and differences between (a) the amounts paid by the employer for OPEBs as the benefits came due and (b) the employer’s proportionate share of the total of certain amounts paid by the employer and nonemployer contributing entities for OPEBs as the benefits came due.
Deferred Outflows of Resources, Other Items
Consumption of other net assets not classified elsewhere that applies to a future period(s) and so will not be recognized as an outflow of resources (expense/expenditure) until then.
Deferred Outflows of Resources, Pension Items
Consumption of pension related net assets that applies to a future period(s) and so will not be recognized as an outflow of resources (expense/expenditure) until then. May also include OPEB items.
Deferred Outflows of Resources, Pension Items, Changes in Assumptions

Consumption of pension related net assets deferred due to changes in assumptions about future economic and demographic factors such as inflation, health care costs trend rates, salary changes, ad hoc post‐employment benefit changes, and mortality rates. Applies to a future period(s) and so will not be recognized as an outflow of resources (expense/expenditure) until then.
Deferred Outflows of Resources, Pension Items, Contributions Made After Measurement Date

Consumption of pension related net assets due to contributions to the pension plan made subsequent to the measurement date and prior to the reporting date. Applies to a future period(s) and so will not be recognized as an outflow of resources (expense/expenditure) until then.
Deferred Outflows of Resources, Pension Items, Difference between Expected and Actual Experience

Consumption of pension related net assets deferreed due to differences between expected and actuarial experience with regard to economic or demographic factors. Applies to a future period(s) and so will not be recognized as an outflow of resources (expense/expenditure) until then.
Deferred Outflows of Resources, Pension Items, Net Difference Projected and Actual Earnings on Pension Plan Investments

Consumption of pension related net assets arising from difference between projected and actual pension plan investment earnings. Applies to a future period(s) and so will not be recognized as an outflow of resources (expense/expenditure) until then.
Deferred Outflows of Resources, Pensions, Changes in Proportion and Differences Between Employer Contributions and Share of Contributions

Consumption of net assets applicable to changes in the employer’s proportion and differences between (a) the amounts paid by the employer for pensions as the benefits came due and (b) the employer’s proportionate share of the total of certain amounts paid by the employer and nonemployer contributing entities for pensions as the benefits came due
Deferred Outflows of Resources
Deferred outflows of resources.
Assets and Deferred Outflows of Resources
Summation of assets and deferred outflows of resources.
Liabilities [Abstract]
Information about liabilities.
Current Liabilities [Abstract]
Information about Current Liabilities.
Regulatory Liability, Current
Regulatory liability, classified as current.
Accrued Tuition and Fees
Accrued tuition and fees.
Bond Interest Payable
The unpaid portion of interest due to the issuance of bonds.
Bonds Payable, Current
The balance of bonds payable due within one year.
Accrued Wages and Related Liabilities Payable
Accrued wages and related liabilities payable.
Accrued Interest Payable
Accrued interest payable.
Accrued Expenses Payable
Accrued expenses payable.
Inter Governmental Payable

Inter-governmental balances payable is appropriate where one governmental unit transfers resources to another, such as when states transfer shared revenues to local governments or act as an Intermediary in federally financed programs.
Internal Balances Payable
Internal balances payable, which are the net residual amounts due between governmental and business-type activities.
Leases Payable
Leases payable.
Accounts Payable
Accounts payable is a liability account reflecting amounts owed to private persons or organizations for goods and services received by a government.
Advances from Grantors
Advances from grantors.
Grants Payable
Grants payable.
Taxes Payable
Taxes payable.
Penalties Payable
Penalties payable.
Deposits Held for Others
Deposits payable.
Notes Payable
Notes payable.
Loans Payable
Loans payable.
Claims and Judgments Payable
Claims and judgments payable.
Payables for Contracts
Contractual obligations not yet paid.
Payables for Others

Payables for others which the reporting entity does not separately disclose in the same statement or note. Payables are amounts owed on open accounts to private persons or organizations for goods and services furnished to a government.
Due to Primary Government Entities
Due to primary government entities.
Due to Component Unit
Due to component unit.
Due to Other Government Entities
Amounts due to other government entities that the reporting entity does not separately disclose in the same statement or note.
Due to Fiduciary Funds
Due to fiduciary funds.
Amount Held for Others
Amount held for others that the reporting entity does not separately disclose in the same statement or note.
Due to Entities Funds
Due to entities funds.
Due to Other Funds
Amounts due to other funds that the reporting entity does not separately disclose in the same statement or note.
Due to Others
Amounts due to others that the reporting entity does not separately disclose in the same statement or note.
Retainage Payable
Retainage payable.
Unearned Revenue
Unearned revenue is the amount for which asset recognition criteria have been met, but the amount has not yet been earned.
Securities Lending Obligations, Liability
Securities lending obligations, liability.
Long Term Liabilities, Current
Long-term liabilities, current.
Derivative Instruments Liability, Current
derivative instruments liability, classified as current.
Provisions, Current
Provisions, classified as current.
Performance Bonds Payable, Current
Performance bonds payable, classified as current.
Compensated Absences Payable, Current

Compensated absences payable, classified as current. Compensated absences are compensated time off such as vacation and sick leave, which has been earned by employees and probable that the employer will compensate the employees through paid time off or some other means, such as cash payments at termination or retirement but not yet compensated by the employer.
Bonds and Interest Payable, Current
Amount of bonds and interest payable, classified as current.
Other Current Liabilities

Other current liabilities which the reporting entity does not separately disclose in the same statement or note. Liabilities are amount of obligations for items that have entered into the operating cycle incurred in the acquisition of materials and supplies to be used in providing services; collections received in advance of the performance of services.
Current Liabilities

Current liabilities are amount of obligations for items that have entered into the operating cycle incurred in the acquisition of materials and supplies to be used in providing services; collections received in advance of the performance of services.
Noncurrent Liabilities [Abstract]
Information about noncurrent liabilities.
Bond Payable, Noncurrent
The balance of bonds payable not due within one year.
Regulatory Liability, Noncurrent
Regulatory liability, classified as noncurrent.
Derivative Instruments Liability, Noncurrent
derivative instruments liability, classified as noncurrent.
Provisions, Noncurrent
Provisions, classified as noncurrent.
Performance Bonds Payable, Noncurrent
Performance bonds payable, classified as noncurrent.
Compensated Absences Payable, Noncurrent

Compensated absences payable, classified as noncurrent. Compensated absences are compensated time off such as vacation and sick leave, which has been earned by employees and probable that the employer will compensate the employees through paid time off or some other means, such as cash payments at termination or retirement but not yet compensated by the employer.
Bonds and Interest Payable, Noncurrent
Amount of bonds and interest payable, classified as noncurrent.
Environmental and Disposal Liabilities
Environmental and disposal liabilities.
Loan Guarantee Liabilities
Loan guarantee liabilities, for example direct student loans.
Long Term Liabilities, Noncurrent
Long-term liabilities, noncurrent.
Noncurrent Liabilities Due Within One Year
Noncurrent liabilities, due within one year, which are present obligations to sacrifice resources that the government has little or no discretion to avoid.
Noncurrent Liabilities Due in More Than One Year
Noncurrent liabilities, due in more than one year, which are present obligations to sacrifice resources that the government has little or no discretion to avoid.
Net Pension Liability
Net pension liability.
Net OPEB Liability

An employer's net OPEB obligation is defined as the cumulative difference between annual OPEB cost and the employer's contributions to a plan, including the OPEB liability or asset at transition, if any. Use this concept when there is an OPEB liability.
Other Noncurrent Liabilities

Other noncurrent liabilities which the reporting entity does not separately disclose in the same statement or note. Liabilities are amount of obligations for items that have entered into the operating cycle incurred in the acquisition of materials and supplies to be used in providing services; collections received in advance of the performance of services.
Noncurrent Liabilities
noncurrent liabilities, which are present obligations to sacrifice resources that the government has little or no discretion to avoid.
Payable from Restricted Assets
Amounts owed for goods and services received by a government, payable from restricted assets.
Liabilities
Liabilities are present obligations to sacrifice resources that the government has little or no discretion to avoid. See GASB COD Appendix B under the summary.
Deferred Inflows of Resources [Abstract]
Information about deferred inflows of resources
Deferred Inflows of Resources, Pension Items, Changes in Assumptions

Acquisition of pension related net assets deferred due to changes in assumptions about future economic and demographic factors such as inflation, health care costs trend rates, salary changes, ad hoc post‐employment benefit changes, and mortality rates. Applies to a future period(s) and so will not be recognized as an inflow of resources (revenue) until then.
Deferred Inflows of Resources, Debt Items
Acquisition of debt related net assets that applies to a future period(s) and so will not be recognized as an inflow of resources (revenue) until that time.
Deferred Inflows of Resources, OPEB Items
Acquisition of OPEB related net assets that applies to a future period(s) and so will not be recognized as an inflow of resources (revenue) until that time.
Deferred Inflows of Resources, OPEB Items, Changes in Assumptions

Acquisition of OPEB related net assets deferred due to changes in assumptions about future economic and demographic factors such as inflation, health care costs trend rates, salary changes, ad hoc post‐employment benefit changes, and mortality rates. Applies to a future period(s) and so will not be recognized as an inflow of resources (revenue) until then.
Deferred Inflows of Resources, OPEB Items, Contributions Made After Measurement Date

Acquisition of OPEB related net assets due to contributions to the OPEB plan made subsequent to the measurement date and prior to the reporting date. Applies to a future period(s) and so will not be recognized as an inflow of resources (revenue) until then.
Deferred Inflows of Resources, OPEB Items, Difference between Expected and Actual Experience

Acquisition of OPEB related net assets deferred due to differences between expected and actuarial experience with regard to economic or demographic factors. Applies to a future period(s) and so will not be recognized as an inflow of resources (revenue) until then.
Deferred Inflows of Resources, OPEB Items, Net Difference Projected and Actual Earnings on Pension Plan Investments

Acquisition of OPEB related net assets arising from difference between projected and actual OPEB plan investment earnings. Applies to a future period(s) and so will not be recognized as an inflow of resources (revenue) until then.
Deferred Inflows of Resources, OPEB, Changes in Proportion and Differences Between Employer Contributions and Share of Contributions

Acquisition of net assets applicable to changes in the employer’s proportion and differences between (a) the amounts paid by the employer for OPEBs as the benefits came due and (b) the employer’s proportionate share of the total of certain amounts paid by the employer and nonemployer contributing entities for OPEBs as the benefits came due.
Deferred Inflows of Resources, Other Items
Acquisition of other net assets not classified elsewhere related net assets that applies to a future period(s) and so will not be recognized as an inflow of resources (revenue) until that time.
Deferred Inflows of Resources, Pension Items
Acquisition of pension related net assets that applies to a future period(s) and so will not be recognized as an inflow of resources (revenue) until that time. May also include OPEB items.
Deferred Inflows of Resources, Pension Items, Contributions Made After Measurement Date

Acquisition of pension related net assets due to contributions to the pension plan made subsequent to the measurement date and prior to the reporting date. Applies to a future period(s) and so will not be recognized as an inflow of resources (revenue) until then.
Deferred Inflows of Resources, Pension Items, Difference between Expected and Actual Experience

Acquisition of pension related net assets deferred due to differences between expected and actuarial experience with regard to economic or demographic factors. Applies to a future period(s) and so will not be recognized as an inflow of resources (revenue) until then.
Deferred Inflows of Resources, Pension Items, Net Difference Projected and Actual Earnings on Pension Plan Investments

Acquisition of pension related net assets arising from difference between projected and actual pension plan investment earnings. Applies to a future period(s) and so will not be recognized as an inflow of resources (revenue) until then.
Deferred Inflows of Resources, Pensions, Changes in Proportion and Differences Between Employer Contributions and Share of Contributions

Acquisition of net assets applicable to changes in the employer’s proportion and differences between (a) the amounts paid by the employer for pensions as the benefits came due and (b) the employer’s proportionate share of the total of certain amounts paid by the employer and nonemployer contributing entities for pensions as the benefits came due
Deferred Inflows of Resources, Unavailable Property Tax Revenue
Accumulation of property tax revenue that applies to a future period(s) and so will not be recognized as an inflow of resources (revenue) until that time.
Deferred Inflows of Resources
Deferred inflows of resources represents an acquisition of net position by the government that is applicable to a future reporting period.
Liabilities and Deferred Inflows of Resources
Summation of liabilities and deferred inflows of resources.
Net Position [Abstract]
Information about net position.
Net Investment in Capital Assets
Net investment in capital assets.
Unrestricted Net Position

Net position represents the difference between all other elements in a statement of financial position and should be displayed in three components namely net investment in capital assets, restricted (separately reporting expendable and nonexpendable components), and unrestricted.. This balance represents the unrestricted portion of Net position.
Restricted Net Position

Net position represents the difference between all other elements in a statement of financial position and should be displayed in three components, namely net investment in capital assets, restricted (separately reporting expendable and nonexpendable components), and unrestricted. This balance represents the restricted postion of Net Position.
Net Position

Net position represents the difference between all other elements in a statement of net position and should be displayed in three components namely net investment in capital assets, restricted (distinguishing between major categories of restrictions), and unrestricted. Use PeriodEnd or PeriodStart labels to represent end of period or start of period balance.
Name of Other Current Assets [Axis]
Used as an identifier for the name of other current assets.
Name of Capital Assets, Non Depreciable [Axis]
Used as an identifier for the name of capital assets, non-depreciable.

Represents information related to a component unit and covers extraneous reporting.
Component Unit Discretely Presented [Member]

Legally separate organizations for which the elected officials of the primary government are financially accountable. In addition, a component unit can be another organization for which the nature and significance of its relationship with a primary government is such that exclusion would cause the reporting entity's financial statements to be misleading or incomplete.

Type of Program Revenues [Axis]
Used to identify type of program revenues which can be from charges for services and sales, from charges for operating grants and contributions, or from capital grants and contributions.
Type of Program Revenues [Domain]
Used to identify type of program revenues which can be from charges for services and sales, from charges for operating grants and contributions, or from capital grants and contributions.
Program Revenues from Charges for Services and Sales [Member]

Program revenues from charges for services. Charges for services arise from charges to customers, applicants, or others who purchase, use, or directly benefit from the goods, services, or privileges provided, or are otherwise directly affected by the services. May include revenues from charges for sales.
Program Revenues from Operating Grants and Contributions [Member]

Program revenues from operating grants and contributions. Program revenues are amounts derived directly from the program itself or from parties outside the reporting government's taxpayers or citizenry, as a whole; they reduce the net cost of the function to be financed from the government's general revenues.
Program Revenues from Capital Grants and Contributions [Member]

Program revenues from capital grants and contributions. Program revenues are amounts derived directly from the program itself or from parties outside the reporting government's taxpayers or citizenry, as a whole; they reduce the net cost of the function to be financed from the government's general revenues.

Activities Expenses For Programs and Functions [Abstract]
Information about expenses for programs and functions on the Statement of Activities.
Expenses For Public Safety Services
Expenses for public safety services..
Expenses For Public Health and Sanitation Services

Expenses for public health and sanitation services..It includes all public health activities; except provision of hospital care. Includes: environmental health activities, health regulation and inspection, water and air pollution control, mosquito control, animal control warden, inspection of food handling establishments, ambulance and paramedic services. not part of a fire department, public health nursing, vital statistics collection, all other services. performed directly by the public health department but excludes payments under public welfare programs.
Expenses For Public Works Services
Expenses for public works services.
Expenses For Public Schools Services
Expenses for public schools services.
Expenses For Public Ways and Facilities Services
Expenses for public ways and facilities services.
Expenses For Public Assistance Services
Expenses for public assistance services.
Expenses For Other Public Services

Expenses for other public services when the reporting entity does not separately disclose in the same statement or note. Includes support of, and assistance to, needy persons, including expenditures from State and Federal grants. Includes: money paid directly to needy persons covered by Federal aid programs (e.g., Temporary Assistance for Needy Families), money paid directly to needy persons not covered by Federal aid programs (e.g., general relief, home relief, poor relief, etc.), payments to landlords, utilities, vendors, etc., for rent, goods, and services. furnished to needy persons, other than for medical and hospital care, payments to private vendors for medical and hospital care provided to needy persons excluding payments to hospital or health agencies operated by this government, welfare institutions operated by this government, including nursing homes, veterans’ homes, homes for the elderly, and indigent care institutions, other public welfare - Administration of relief and assistance, foster care, related community action programs, and other welfare activities not reported. Excludes: any payments to the State for this government’s share of the welfare costs.
Expenses For Security of Persons and Property Services

Expenses for security of persons and property services. Includes a) police agencies for preventing, controlling, or reducing crime; law enforcement activities of sheriff and constable offices; coroners; medical examiners; vehicular inspection activities; traffic control and safety activities; lock-up operations and excludes contributions to a local police pension fund, local court activities, and local correction activities, b) firefighting and fire prevention and ambulance and paramedic services handled by the fire department, contributions of volunteer fire units, but excludes contributions to a local fire pension fund, forest fire protection amounts.
Expenses For Community Development Services
Expenses for community development services.
Expenses For Economic Development Services
Expenses for economic development services.
Expenses For Other Development Services
Expenses for other development services when the reporting entity does not separately disclose in the same statement or note.
Expenses For Conservation, Recreation, Parks and Cultural Services

Expenses for conservation, recreation, parks and cultural services. Includes provision and support of recreational and cultural-scientific facilities and activities including golf courses, play fields, playgrounds, public beaches, swimming pools, tennis courts, parks, auditoriums, stadiums, auto camps, recreation piers, marinas, botanical gardens, galleries, museums, and zoos. Also includes building and operation of convention centers and exhibition halls.
Expenses For Transportation Services
Expenses for transportation services.
Expenses For Education Services
Expenses for education services.
Expenses For Electricity and Power Services
Expenses for electricity and power services.
Expenses For General Government Services, Legislative and Executive
Expenses for general government services, legislative and executive.
Expenses For General Government Services, Judicial

Expenses for general government, classified as judicial. Includes all county or municipal court and court-related activities including juries, probate officials, prosecutors, bailiffs, marshals, public defenders, attorneys, legal departments, and court activities of sheriffs departments and excludes all activities related to probation and parole.

Debt servicing of interest and fiscal charges. Interest and fiscal charges covers debt service payments other than principal repayment.
Cost of Issue of Bonds and Securities
Cost of issue of bonds and securities.
Other Expenses
Other expenses which the reporting entity does not separately disclose in the same statement or note.
Expenses

Expenses, which includes an entity's outflows or expiration of assets or the incurrence of liabilities during a period from providing or producing goods, rendering services, or carrying out other activities.
Net (Expense) Revenue
Net of expenses and revenues.

Statement of Activities, General Revenues and Changes in Net Position [Line Items]
Used to collect information about revenue sourced from specific programs.
Activities General Revenues [Abstract]
Information about General Revenues on the Statement of Activities.
Revenue From Property Tax
Revenue from property taxes.Property taxes are ad-valorem taxes levied on an assessed valuation of real property.
Revenue From Income Tax
Revenue from income tax which are taxes derived from state, municipal or school district income tax.
Revenue From Sales Tax
Revenue from sales tax which is imposed upon the sale or consumption of goods.
Revenue From Usage of Utilities Tax
Revenue from usage of utilities tax which is levied in proportion to gross receipts on public or privately owned public utilities that provide electric, gas, water and/or telephone service.
Revenue From Sales and Use Tax
Revenue from sales and use tax.
Revenue From Business License Tax
Revenue from business license tax.
Revenue From Property Transfer Tax
Revenue from property transfer tax.
Revenue From Documents Transfer Tax
Revenue from documents transfer tax.
Revenue From Transfer Stamps Tax
Revenue from transfer stamps tax.
Revenue From Hotel and Motel Tax
Revenue from hotel and motel tax.
Revenue From Vehicles Tax
Revenue from vehicles tax.
Revenue From Transient Occupancy Tax
Revenue from transient occupancy tax.
Revenue From Parking occupancy Tax
Revenue from parking occupancy tax.
Revenue From Meals Tax
Revenue from meals tax.
Revenue From Franchise Income Tax
Revenue from franchise income tax.
Revenue From Other Taxes
Revenue from other taxes when the reporting entity does not separately disclose in the same statement or note.
Revenue From Taxes
All revenue generated from taxes.
Revenue From Receipts in Lieu of Tax
Revenue from receipts in lieu of tax.
Revenue From Special Assessments

Revenue from special assessments. Compulsory contributions and reimbursements from owners of property benefited by improvements (example, streets, sewers, sidewalks, water extensions and likewise) as well as for servicing special assessment debt. Excludes: proceeds from sales of special assessment bonds and maintenance assessments.
Revenue From Shared Revenue
Revenue from shared Revenue.
Revenue From Investment Income
Revenue from investment income which is compensation for the use of financial resources over a period of time.
Revenue From Licenses and Permits and Franchise Fees

Revenue from licenses and permits and franchise fees. License and permit fees exacted (either for revenue raising or for regulation) as a condition to the exercise of a business or non-business privilege.
Revenue From Fines and Forfeitures and Penalties
Revenue from fines and forfeitures and penalties are obtained through penalties and other law enforcement or court activities.
Revenue From Use of Money and Property
Revenue from use of money and property.
Revenue From Inter Governmental Activities

Revenue from inter-governmental activities is appropriate where one governmental unit transfers resources to another, such as when states transfer shared revenues to local governments or act as an intermediary in federally financed programs.
Revenue From Grants and Entitlements for Specific Programs
Revenue from grants and entitlements for specific programs.
Gain (Loss) on Sale of Capital Assets
Gain (loss) on sale of capital assets.
Changes in Fair Value of Investments

Changes in fair value of investments. Investment amounts pertaining to a security or other asset that (a) a government holds primarily for the purpose of income or profit and (b) has a present service capacity based solely on its ability to generate cash or to be sold to generate cash.
Contributions from Primary Government
Contributions from primary government.
Recovery of Cost Incurred
Recovery of cost incurred.
Earnings on Endowments and Permanent Fund Investments
Earnings on endowments and permanent fund investments.
General Revenues, Net
General revenues, net.
Revenues, Net
Revenues, net.
Other General Revenues

Other general revenues which the reporting entity does not separately disclose in the same statement or note. All revenues are general revenues unless they are required to be reported as program revenues.
Special and Extraordinary Items
Special and extraordinary items.
Adjustments for Transfer of Revenues Within Activities

Adjustments for transfer of revenues within activities which includes a) significant transactions or other events within the control of management that are either unusual in nature or infrequent in occurrence are special items. Special items should also be reported separately in the statement of activities, before extraordinary items, if any. In addition, governments should disclose in the notes to financial statements any significant transactions or other events that are either unusual or infrequent but not within the control of management, b) extraordinary items that are transactions or other events that are both unusual in nature and infrequent in occurrence. Extraordinary items should be reported separately at the bottom of the statement of activities, c) contribution to permanent fund are amounts remitted to funds whose principal balances may not be legally expended.
Activities Changes in Net Position [Abstract]
Information about Net Position on the Statement of Activities.
Net Position at Beginning of Period (Before Adjustment)
Adjustments in Net Position for Restatements (Errors and Accounting Policy)
Adjustments in net position for restatements (errors and accounting policy). Amounts are reflected as adjustments to the opening balance of the net position.
Net Position at Beginning of Period (After Adjustments)
Net position at beginning of period (after adjustments). Amounts reflected as the opening balance of net position after adjustments.
Net Position at End of Period
Changes in Net Position
Changes in net position which is the difference in net position between the beginning and end of the reporting period.
Name of Other Program Using Revenues [Axis]
Used as an identifier for the name of other program for which revenues are to be used, for example, "Revenue used for school literacy programs."

Items that appear on the Statement of Activities.

Used as an identifier for the name of other general revenues. Use with the concept OtherGeneralRevenues.
Name of Adjustments for Transfer of Revenues Within Activities [Axis]
Used as an identifier for the name of adjustments for transfer of revenues within activities. Use with the concept AdjustmentForTransferOfRevenuesWithinActivities.
Name of Other Expenses [Axis]
Used as an identifier for the name of other expenses not elsewhere classified. Should be used with the OtherExpenses concept.

Information on the Governmental Funds Balance Sheet.
Governmental Funds Balance Sheet [Table]
Report the CAFR statement number and table number for which hypercube (table) has been used
Fund Identifier [Axis]

Used to represent a governmental fund. If the fund is General or Aggregate Nonmajor, should be used with the enumerated element FundType with value reported as General Fund or Aggregate Nonmajor. If the fund is categorized as Special Revenue, Capital Project, Debt Service, Permanent, or Other, use the FundType element to indicate the fund type, and use the element FundName to specify the government-specific fund name, for example "Public Education" or "Transportation". FundName should not be used for funds that are categorized as General Fund or Aggregate Nonmajor.
Governmental Funds Balance Sheet [Line Items]
Used to report information found on the Governmental Funds Balance Sheet.
Fund Name

Name of a fund which has a fund type of Special Revenue, Capital Project, Debt Services, Permanent, or Other. When using this element, also use the element FundType to select the type of fund, and the FundIdentifierAxis.
Fund Type

Indicates the type of fund which can be Special Revenue, Capital Project, Debt Services, Permanent, Other, General, or Aggregate Nonmajor. If the fund is Special Revenue, Capital Project, Debt Service, Permanent, or Other, this element should be used with the FundName element to identify the government fund, and with the FundIdentifierAxis. If it is a General Fund or Aggregate Nonmajor Fund, use it with the FundIdentifierAxis but do not use the FundName element.
Restricted Investments

Investments which are not defined as or included in marketable (debt, equity, or other) securities whose use is restricted in whole or in part, generally by contractual agreements or regulatory requirements. For use in an unclassified balance sheet.
Other Investments

Other investments which the reporting entity does not separately disclose in the same statement or note. Investment income is the compensation for the use of financial resources over a period of time.
Inventories
Inventories, which are materials and supplies on hand for future consumption or goods held for resale rather than for use in operations.
Advances to Other Funds
Advances to other funds that the reporting entity does not separately disclose in the same statement or note.
Inter Funds Balances Receivable

Inter-funds balances receivable which have a requirement for repayment, and which are reported as inter-fund receivables in lender funds and inter-fund payables in borrower funds. This activity should not be reported as other financing sources or uses in the fund financial statements. If repayment is not expected within a reasonable time, the inter-fund balances should be reduced and the amount that is not expected to be repaid should be reported as a transfer from the fund that made the loan to the fund that received the loan.
OPEB, Asset

Other post-employment benefits plan, classified as asset. Represents the government's total liability for other post-employment benefits less the fiduciary net position of OPEB plans in which the government has an interest.
Regulatory Assets
Regulatory assets.
Derivative Instruments, Assets
Derivative instruments which is an asset.
Net Assets
Net assets.
Other Assets
Other assets which the reporting entity does not separately disclose in the same statement or note. Assets are resources with present service capacity that the government presently controls.
Net Assets and Deferred Outflows of Resources
Net assets and deferred outflows of resources.
Advances from Other Funds
Advances from other funds that the reporting entity does not separately disclose in the same statement or note.
Inter Funds Balances Payable

Inter-funds balances payable, which have a requirement for repayment, and which are reported as inter-fund receivables in lender funds and inter-fund payables in borrower funds. This activity should not be reported as other financing sources or uses in the fund financial statements. If repayment is not expected within a reasonable time, the inter-fund balances should be reduced and the amount that is not expected to be repaid should be reported as a transfer from the fund that made the loan to the fund that received the loan.
OPEB Liability

Other post-employment benefits plan, classified as liability, defined as the government's total liability for other post-employment benefits less the fiduciary net position of OPEB plans in which the government has an interest.
Regulatory Liability
Regulatory liability.
Derivative Instruments, Liability
Derivative instruments, a liability.
Provisions
Provisions.

Performance bonds payable.
Compensated Absences Payable

Compensated absences payable are compensated time off such as vacation and sick leave, which has been earned by employees and probable that the employer will compensate the employees through paid time off or some other means, such as cash payments at termination or retirement but not yet compensated by the employer.
Bonds and Interest Payable
Amount of bonds and interest payable.
Long Term Liabilities
Long-term liabilities.
Other Liabilities

Other liabilities which the reporting entity does not separately disclose in the same statement or note. Liabilities are present obligations to sacrifice resources that the government has little or no discretion to avoid.

Compensated absences payable, matured.

Bond and interest payable, matured.

Revenues [Abstract]
Information about revenues.
Revenue From Grants and Entitlements Restricted for Specific Programs
Revenue from grants and entitlement programs restricted for specific programs.
Revenue From Grants and Entitlements Not Restricted for Specific Programs
Revenue from grants and entitlement programs not restricted for specific programs.
Revenue From Charges for Services and Sales

Revenue from charges for services and sales. Charges for services includes charges to customers, applicants, or others who purchase, use, or directly benefit from the goods, services, or privileges provided, or are otherwise directly affected by the services. Includes revenue from fees charged for specific services, such as water use or garbage collection; licenses and permits, such as dog licenses, liquor licenses, and building permits; operating special assessments, such as for street cleaning or special street lighting; and any other amounts charged to service recipients. Fines and forfeitures are also included in this category because they result from direct charges to those who are otherwise directly affected by a program or service, even though they receive no benefit. Should also include payments from other governments for goods or services—for example, when County A reimburses County B for boarding County A's prisoners.
Revenue From Services to Enterprise Funds
Revenue from services to enterprise funds.
Grants, Contributions and Donations from Federal Governmental Entities
Grants, contributions and donations from federal governmental entities.
Grants, Contributions and Donations from State Governmental Entities
Grants, contributions and donations from state governmental entities.
Grants, Contributions and Donations from Others
Grants, contributions and donations from others when the reporting entity does not separately disclose in the same statement or note.
Other Revenues
Other revenues which the reporting entity does not separately disclose in the same statement or note.
Revenues

Revenues that are generated by a government itself, such as tax revenues and water and sewer charges. Investment income is also an own-source revenue. Intergovernmental aid and shared revenues are not own-source revenues.
